According to the Pew Research Center survey, there is a significant difference in the perceptions of Republicans and Democrats regarding China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are significantly more critical of China, with a higher percentage viewing China's actions as contributing to the global spread of the virus and having a very unfavorable view of the country. For instance, 82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [9]. Moreover, 61% of Republicans believe China had done a very bad job handling the outbreak, compared to just 30% of Democrats [9].

Additionally, the survey found that 73% of Republicans think China's early handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its spread, compared to 38% of Democrats [10]. Furthermore, when asked whether the U.S. should hold China responsible for the role it played in the outbreak, 71% of Republicans said yes, even if it means worsening economic relations, compared to 37% of Democrats [11]. This reflects a more adversarial stance among Republicans towards China.

![Republicans and Democrats' differing views on China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak](image5)

In contrast, Democrats and Democratic leaners tend to be more lenient, with a smaller proportion criticizing China's actions. They are less likely to blame China for the global spread of the virus and are more inclined to prioritize strong U.S.-China relations even if it means overlooking China's role in the outbreak.

Overall, the data from the Pew Research Center survey indicates that Republicans and Democrats differ significantly in their perceptions of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, with Republicans being more critical and emphasizing accountability, while Democrats are more focused on maintaining positive relations despite criticisms.

According to the survey data, there is a significant difference in how Republicans and Democrats perceive China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. [2] and [4] show that Republicans are substantially more critical of China's actions compared to Democrats. Specifically, [2] indicates that 73% of Republicans believe the Chinese government's initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan contributed a great deal to the global spread of the virus, compared to 38% of Democrats. Similarly, [4] reveals that 82% of Republicans think China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, whereas only 54% of Democrats share this view. Furthermore, [7] highlights that those who think China has done a poor job handling the outbreak are significantly more likely to have negative views of the country. For instance, 85% of those who say China has done a poor job handling the pandemic have an unfavorable view of the country, compared to 53% among those who think China is doing a good job.

The perception of China's role in the pandemic has also shifted over time. [6] and [8] demonstrate that while negative views of China have increased across the political spectrum, the criticism is more pronounced among Republicans. In particular, [6] notes that among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, who were split nearly evenly last year, a majority (63%) now believe bilateral economic ties are bad, a 15-point increase from the previous year. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents have also become more negative, with roughly three-quarters (73%) saying ties are bad, up 12 points from a year prior. [12] further supports this trend, showing that around two-thirds (64%) of Americans say China has done a bad job, including 43% who say it has done a very bad job. When a similar question was asked in April and May, 63% of Americans said China was doing only a fair or a poor job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak.

In summary, the data from [2], [4], [7], [6], and [12] clearly indicate that Republicans are more critical of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and that these perceptions have intensified over time. ![Republicans and Democrats' differing views on China's handling of the pandemic](image1)

According to the survey data, Americans largely view China's role in the coronavirus outbreak negatively. A significant majority of 64% believe that China has handled the coronavirus outbreak badly, with 43% saying it has done a very bad job [4]. This negative perception is particularly pronounced among Republicans and older individuals. For instance, 73% of those aged 50 and older believe China’s early handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its spread, compared to just 38% of Democrats [9].

The Pew Research Center survey also indicates that half of Americans think the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the pandemic, even if it means worsening economic relations [3]. This sentiment is more prevalent among Republicans and those who lean towards the GOP, with 71% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents supporting this stance, compared to only 37% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [3].

Moreover, there is a clear trend in the shift of public opinion regarding the U.S.'s relationship with China. As seen in image1, the perception of China as "Bad" has increased from 53% in 2019 to 68% in 2020, while the perception of China as "Good" has decreased from 41% to 30%. This trend is even more pronounced among Republicans, where the perception of China as "Bad" rose from 54% to 82%, and as "Good" dropped from 41% to 15% [11].

The demographic breakdown further illustrates these trends. As depicted in image2, older Americans and those who identify as Republicans are significantly more critical of China. For example, 73% of those aged 50 and above and 82% of Republicans/Republican-leaning individuals perceive China's handling of the coronavirus as "Bad." In contrast, younger adults and Democrats are less critical, with 51% of those aged 18-29 and 54% of Democrats perceiving China's handling as "Bad" [11].

These sentiments are reflected in the broader context of U.S. policy towards China. Image6 shows that the preference for a tougher stance towards China has been on the rise, from 35% in 2018 to 46% in 2020, while the desire for a stronger relationship has declined, from 62% in 2018 to 51% in 2020 [6].

In summary, the data reveals a growing skepticism towards China among Americans, particularly among Republicans and older generations, with a significant portion of the population advocating for a more adversarial relationship. This shift is evident in both the perception of China's role in the coronavirus outbreak and the broader U.S.-China relations, with younger adults and Democrats being more inclined to prioritize economic relations and human rights over a tough stance.

According to the data, views on China have become increasingly negative across various age groups and political affiliations, but the trends differ slightly depending on age and political affiliation.

### Age Groups
- **18-29**: The percentage of those with an unfavorable view of China has risen from 26% in 2005 to 56% in 2020 [6]. This increase is notable, though it remains lower than other age groups.
- **30-49**: This group has seen a more significant rise, with the unfavorable view increasing from 41% in 2005 to 67% in 2020 [6].
- **50 and older**: The most dramatic change is observed in this group, where the unfavorable view has surged from 34% in 2005 to 81% in 2020 [6].

### Political Affiliations
- **Republicans and Republican-leaning independents**: These groups consistently hold more unfavorable views of China. In 2020, 83% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents viewed China unfavorably [4], compared to 68% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents.
- **Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents**: While still negative, the unfavorable view is lower than that of Republicans, at 68% in 2020 [4].

### Trends Over Time
- **Overall**: The share of Americans with an unfavorable view of China has increased from 46% in 2015 to 73% in 2020, marking the highest level of negativity in 15 years [7].
- **Republican Views**: The negative sentiment among Republicans has grown significantly, increasing by 11 percentage points over the past four months alone [9].
- **Democratic Views**: Unfavorable views among Democrats have increased by 6 percentage points over the same period [9].

![The trends in unfavorable views of China over time show a significant increase among all groups, particularly among Republicans and those aged 50 and older.](image1)
![The unfavorable views of China increase across all age groups, with the most significant increase observed in the 50 and older demographic.](image2)

These trends indicate a consistent shift towards more negative perceptions of China, with older Americans and Republicans being the most critical. The image1 and image2 graphs illustrate these changes clearly, showing the upward trend in unfavorable views across different age groups and political affiliations.

In conclusion, views on China have become increasingly negative across all age groups, with the most pronounced increase among those aged 50 and older and Republicans.

According to the data, negative opinions of China have increased significantly over the years, particularly among older Americans and those with more conservative political leanings. A line graph from 2005 to 2020 (`image2`) shows that Republicans' unfavorable views of China have surged from 39% in 2005 to a peak of 83% in 2020, while Democrats' unfavorable views have risen from 34% to 68% during the same period. This reflects a widening gap between the two parties, with Republicans becoming notably more negative towards China (`image9`).

The trend is especially pronounced among older Americans, with a significant increase in negative views. For instance, the percentage of Americans aged 50 and older with an unfavorable view of China has climbed from 34% in 2005 to 81% in 2020 (`image8`). Similarly, younger Americans have also become more negative, though at a slower rate. The "18-29" age group, for example, saw its unfavorable view rise from 26% in 2005 to 56% in 2020 (`image8`).

Moreover, the shift is evident in the overall sentiment towards China, with a July 2020 survey indicating that 73% of Americans have an unfavorable view of the country, marking a 26-point increase since 2018 (`image5`).

![Older Americans turn even more negative toward China in recent months](image10)
As seen in the bar chart (`image6`), the unfavorable view among those aged 50 and older has increased from 67% to 81%, while the favorable view has dropped from 14% to just 14%. For the 18-29 age group, the unfavorable view rose from 26% to 56%, and the favorable view fell from 36% to 22%.

These shifts are also reflected in specific attitudes towards China's handling of the coronavirus pandemic. While majorities in all age groups now hold unfavorable views, the increase is most stark among the older demographic (`image7`).

In summary, negative opinions of China have grown among all age groups but are particularly pronounced among older Americans and those with more conservative political affiliations.

According to the data, there has been a significant shift in perceptions regarding China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic across various age groups and political affiliations. The majority of Americans, regardless of age, now hold an unfavorable view of China, but older Americans and Republicans are notably more critical.

For instance, around three-quarters of Americans believe that the Chinese government's initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan contributed either a great deal or a fair amount to the global spread of the virus ([7]). Specifically, 73% of Republicans believe that China's early handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its spread, compared to just 38% of Democrats who share this view. This stark difference highlights the partisan divide in perceptions of China's actions during the pandemic ([10]).

Moreover, the Pew Research Center's survey data indicates that older Americans, particularly those aged 50 and above, are significantly more negative toward China than younger counterparts. For instance, 81% of those aged 50 and older have an unfavorable view of China, which is a 10 percentage point increase since March ([6]). This trend is consistent with the general unfavorable views of China, which have been increasing over the past decade, with Republicans holding more negative views than Democrats ([11]).

The visual representation in `image5` provides a clear picture of these trends. It shows that for the total population, 73% have an unfavorable view of China, while only 22% have a favorable view. Among the age groups, the unfavorable view is particularly pronounced for those aged 50 and older, where 81% have an unfavorable view, compared to 56% for those aged 18-29 and 71% for those aged 30-49 ([5], [6], [11]). The political affiliation further exacerbates these differences, with 83% of Republicans having an unfavorable view, compared to 68% of Democrats ([11]).

The `image4` chart also illustrates these trends by breaking down the perceptions of China's handling of the pandemic across different demographic groups. It shows that among the total population, 64% perceive China's handling as "Bad," with this sentiment being even stronger among older Americans and Republicans. For instance, 73% of those aged 50 and older and 82% of Republicans perceive China's handling as "Bad" ([10]).

In summary, the perception of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic has become increasingly unfavorable across all age groups, but the differences are most pronounced among older Americans and Republicans. This aligns with the broader trend of growing unfavorable views of China over the past decade, with Republicans consistently holding more negative views than Democrats.

![Americans are highly critical of the way China has handled the coronavirus outbreak. Around two-thirds (64%) say China has done a bad job, including 43% who say it has done a very bad job.](image3)

The perception of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak varies significantly among different age groups and political affiliations. According to the data from image3, older Americans, specifically those aged 50 and above, are particularly critical, with 81% having an unfavorable view. This is significantly higher compared to younger age groups, where only 54% of those aged 30-49 and 56% of those aged 18-29 view China unfavorably. 

Moreover, political affiliation plays a significant role. Image5, which tracks the trends from 2005 to 2020, shows that Republicans and those leaning Republican (Rep/Lean Rep) have consistently held more unfavorable views, peaking at 83% in 2020, compared to Democrats and those leaning Democratic (Dem/Lean Dem), who reached 68% in the same year. This gap is further highlighted by the fact that 61% of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals believe China has done a very bad job, compared to just 30% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals.

In summary, both age and political affiliation strongly influence perceptions of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak. Older Americans and Republicans are notably more critical of China's actions.

According to the data, political affiliations in the U.S. significantly influence preferences for foreign policy partners and desired cooperation levels. In the U.S., both Republicans and Democrats agree that the UK is their most important foreign policy partner, but there are notable differences in preferences for other countries. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more inclined towards Israel as a partner, with 26% choosing it compared to only 9% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents. Democrats, on the other hand, place more emphasis on Canada and Mexico, with 14% and 15% respectively, as top foreign policy affiliates. However, when it comes to Germany, both sides rank it similarly, with both ranking Germany fifth on the list of most important foreign policy partners ([2], [3]). This indicates a degree of bipartisan agreement on Germany's importance despite other differences.

In Germany, political parties exhibit varying preferences for foreign policy partners. Supporters of the CDU/CSU and SPD name France as the first or second-most important partner, followed by the U.S. ([7]). Meanwhile, the Greens tend to prioritize the EU over individual countries, which could influence their stance on foreign policy. The image2 shows this divergence, highlighting that while Germans are more likely to view the U.S. as an important partner, Americans do not reciprocate the same level of interest in Germany ([2], [8]).

Moreover, the desire for cooperation between the U.S. and Germany is influenced by political affiliations. A majority of Americans (69%) want to cooperate more with Germany, while fewer Germans (50%) feel the same way about the U.S. ([8]). This suggests a significant gap in mutual cooperation desires. Additionally, there are slight partisan differences within the U.S., with Democrats being more likely to want greater cooperation with Germany (66%) compared to Republicans (57%), while Republicans are more inclined to favor closer ties with Russia (31%) compared to Democrats (21%) ([11]).

The image7 provides further insight, showing that a majority of Americans (61%) prefer Germany over Russia, while a larger proportion of Germans (50%) prefer the U.S. over Russia. This preference is mirrored in the desire for cooperation, with more Americans wanting to cooperate with Germany (69%) compared to Germans wanting to cooperate with the U.S. (50%).

In conclusion, political affiliations in the U.S. and Germany play a crucial role in shaping preferences for foreign policy partners and desired levels of cooperation, often leading to divergent views between the two countries.

According to the data, Americans and Germans exhibit distinct preferences for increased cooperation with Russia and China, which can be influenced by their respective political party affiliations.

In the U.S., Democrats are more likely to want greater cooperation with Germany compared to Republicans. Specifically, about two-thirds of Democrats (66%) say they prefer close ties with Germany, compared to 57% of Republicans. Conversely, a greater share of Republicans prefer close relations with Russia (31%) than Democrats (21%). This suggests that Democrats are more inclined towards Germany, while Republicans lean more towards Russia. ![Differences in political party preferences](image2)

In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU (Conservative Union/Christian Social Union) are more willing to want greater cooperation with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD (Social Democratic Party). This aligns with data on the international image of the U.S., where those on the ideological right in Germany tend to be more favorable toward the U.S. overall. Democrats in the U.S. are also more likely to want greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans, indicating a similar pattern of political influence. ![German political party preferences](image3)

Regarding Russia, in the U.S., Republicans are almost twice as likely as Democrats to want greater collaboration. About 41% of Republicans want closer ties with Russia, compared to 32% of Democrats. This partisan divide is mirrored in Germany, where those living in the former East Germany are more likely to prefer a close relationship with Russia (75%) compared to those in the former West (63%). ![Partisan differences in U.S. and Germany](image4)

When it comes to China, the preferences are more nuanced. Younger Americans (ages 18-29) are much more likely than older Americans to want a close relationship with China over Germany. For example, 58% of Americans in this age group say it is more important for their country to have a close relationship with China than with Germany (32%). In contrast, older Americans are more likely to value a relationship with Germany. ![Age differences in U.S. preferences](image7)

Germans, on the other hand, are about twice as likely to say they prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% to 24%). This preference is particularly strong in the former East Germany, where nearly 40% of respondents prefer the U.S. over Russia, compared to only 23% who prefer the U.S. in the former West. ![East vs West Germany preferences](image6)

In summary, the preferences for increased cooperation with Russia and China between Americans and Germans are significantly influenced by political party affiliations. Democrats in the U.S. and supporters of the CDU/CSU in Germany tend to favor closer ties with the U.S. rather than Russia, while Republicans in the U.S. and those in the former East Germany in Germany lean towards Russia. These findings underscore the importance of political alignment in shaping international relationships and preferences. ![Summary of preferences](image8)

In the U.S., there is a notable partisan divide when it comes to the preference for close relationships with Russia and China. Democrats are more inclined to favor Germany over Russia and China, with 66% of Democrats preferring close ties with Germany compared to 57% of Republicans [1]. In contrast, Republicans are more supportive of a close relationship with Russia, with 31% preferring this over Germany, while Democrats are only 21% in favor of a close relationship with Russia [1].

In Germany, the political spectrum also plays a role in attitudes towards cooperation with Russia and China. For instance, supporters of CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and SPD [6]. Moreover, East Germans are more likely to prefer close ties with Russia (39%) compared to West Germans (23%), while West Germans are twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. than with Russia [10].

The image1 provides a visual representation of these preferences. It shows that the U.S. has a higher preference for Germany (50%) compared to China (32%) and Japan (7%), while Germany prefers the U.S. (50%) over China (24%) [image1]. This aligns with the text that indicates a strong preference for the U.S. among Germans, especially those on the right of the political spectrum.

Additionally, the image2 further illustrates the partisan differences in the U.S. and Germany. It shows that 61% of Americans prefer Germany over Russia, while only 26% prefer Russia. Among Germans, 50% prefer the U.S. over Russia, with a significant number (30%) believing in both options [image2]. In terms of China, 41% of Americans prefer Germany, while 44% prefer China. For Germans, 50% prefer the U.S. over China, with 18% believing in both [image2].

The image3 shows that younger Americans (ages 18-29) are more likely to prefer a close relationship with China (58%) over Germany (32%), whereas older Americans are more inclined towards Germany [image3]. This suggests that age may also play a role in shaping these preferences.

In summary, political party preferences significantly influence attitudes towards cooperation with Russia and China. Democrats in the U.S. generally prefer Germany over both Russia and China, while Republicans lean towards Russia. In Germany, the political spectrum also matters, with conservatives being more favorable towards the U.S. and East Germans more inclined towards Russia. These findings underscore the complex interplay between political orientation and international relations.

According to the provided text and image quotes, political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany significantly influence attitudes toward cooperation with Russia. In the U.S., Democrats are more likely to want greater cooperation with Germany compared to Republicans ([3]). Similarly, in Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU (a conservative party) are more willing to want greater cooperation with the U.S. than those supporting the Greens and the SPD (both considered left-leaning parties) ([11]). This trend is also reflected in the differing views on U.S.-German cooperation, where Republicans in the U.S. are more inclined to cooperate with Germany than Democrats, and Germans in the former East prioritize relations with Russia over the U.S., while West Germans prefer a close relationship with the U.S. than with Russia ([9]).

According to the Pew Research Center survey, Americans and Germans have starkly different views on which country is considered the world’s leading economic power. In the U.S., half of the respondents named the U.S. as the leading economic power, while about a third chose China. In contrast, in Germany, roughly half named China as the leading economic power, compared to just 24% who named the U.S. (text quote [3]).

These differing views extend to international relationships. For instance, when asked about the importance of various countries as partners, the image1 shows that while the U.K. is viewed positively by Americans, Germans are more likely to see the U.S. as an important partner. Additionally, the image2 highlights significant differences in approval ratings for international entities like the EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO. Notably, Germans have higher approval ratings for the EU (+18%) and Russia (+17%) compared to Americans (text quote [6]).

Furthermore, the image3 illustrates regional differences in preferences, with East Germans being more inclined to prefer Russia over the U.S., while West Germans are more balanced in their preferences. The image4 provides insights into how political orientation affects perceptions in both countries, with Germans generally having more favorable views of the UN and EU across the political spectrum, while Americans show a larger gap between conservative and liberal views on these entities.

In summary, Americans and Germans significantly differ in their views on the leading economic powers and international relationships, reflecting broader geopolitical and ideological divides (text quote [8]).

According to the data, Americans and Germans have divergent views on international organizations and economic powers. Americans are more likely to view the U.S. as the leading economic power, with 50% naming the U.S. and 32% naming China. In contrast, Germans are more inclined to name China as the leading economic power, with 53% favoring it and 24% favoring the U.S. [7][8]. This disparity can be seen in the bar chart (image1), where the U.S. is viewed as the leading economic power by 50% of Americans but only 24% of Germans, while China is viewed as the leading economic power by 53% of Germans and 24% of Americans.

When it comes to international organizations, the Pew Research Center survey reveals that Germans tend to view these organizations more positively than Americans. For instance, about 70% of Germans favor the EU, compared to just around 50% of Americans. Similarly, the approval rating for the UN is higher among Germans (65%) than Americans (59%). However, both countries share a generally positive view of NATO, with 57% of Germans and 52% of Americans approving of it. The comparative bar chart (image5) illustrates these differences, showing that Germany has significantly higher approval ratings for the EU (+18%), Russia (+17%), China (+8%), and the UN (+6%) compared to the U.S.

The ideological differences also play a significant role in shaping these perceptions. As indicated in quote [11], conservatives in both countries are more likely to view Russia favorably, while liberals tend to favor the UN and EU more. The comparative chart (image6) further supports this, showing that Liberals in the U.S. and Germany are more positive towards the UN and EU, with the Left-Right difference being +42 for the UN and +15 for the EU in the U.S., and +10 for the UN and +15 for the EU in Germany.

In terms of security and defense spending, the survey also highlights a divergence in views between the two countries. Germans tend to view Russia more favorably and the EU less favorably, with 43% of East Germans and 71% of West Germans having a favorable view of Russia, and 59% and 71% of West and East Germans, respectively, favoring the EU. [4]

Overall, the differences in views on international organizations and economic powers between Americans and Germans are influenced by a combination of ideological leanings and historical contexts. These factors contribute to the divergent perceptions, as illustrated by the comparative charts and bar graphs provided.

In both nations, there is a stark difference in perceptions regarding the necessity of military force and defense spending. According to text quote [1], a significantly larger proportion of Americans on the right (90%) believe that military force is necessary, compared to only 65% of liberals. In Germany, 59% of right-wing individuals see military force as necessary, whereas only 33% of left-wing individuals agree. This disparity is further highlighted by text quote [9], where 80% of Americans believe it is sometimes necessary to use force to maintain order in the world, while only 50% of Germans agree.

Regarding defense spending, text quote [3] reveals that in the U.S., the public sentiment has shifted. In 2017, 45% of Americans believed their European allies should increase their defense spending, but by 2019, this figure dropped to 50% supporting no change. In Germany, as shown in image6, public opinion was more evenly split between increasing, maintaining, or decreasing defense spending, with 40% supporting an increase in 2019. This indicates a nuanced view in Germany compared to the more decisive stance in the U.S.

When it comes to the age demographics' views on U.S.-Germany relations, text quote [11] and image3 provide insights. In the U.S., a significant generational divide exists, with 82% of the youngest (18-29) age group viewing the relationship positively, compared to 73% of those aged 65 and older. Image3 visually reinforces this trend, showing that younger Americans are notably more positive about the relationship, with an 11% gap between the youngest and oldest age groups. In Germany, the picture is similar, with 40% of the youngest age group (18-29) seeing the relationship as good, compared to 28% of those 65 and older. This gap is illustrated in the image, indicating a 12% difference between the youngest and oldest age groups.

The image3 also highlights the broader generational perspective, showing that younger individuals in both countries are more positive about the U.S.-Germany relationship. This trend is consistent with the data presented in text quote [11], which states that 82% of Americans aged 18-29 view the relationship positively, compared to 73% of those aged 65 and older. For Germany, 40% of the youngest age group sees the relationship as good, compared to 28% of those aged 65 and older, indicating a 12% gap.

In conclusion, Americans are more likely to see the necessity of military force and support higher defense spending, while Germans are more divided on these issues. Additionally, younger individuals in both countries hold a more positive view of the U.S.-Germany relationship compared to their older counterparts.

![Significant differences in opinions on military force and defense spending](image3)

The opinions of Americans and Germans on military intervention and defense spending show stark contrasts. In the U.S., a substantial majority—60%—believe that it is sometimes necessary to use military force to maintain order in the world, whereas only 34% of Germans share this view [3]. Similarly, when it comes to defense spending, a higher proportion of Americans (50%) think that the U.S.'s European allies should maintain their current levels of spending, while a larger segment of Germans (40%) favor increasing their defense budgets [12].

![Differences in perceived importance of defense spending](image2)

Furthermore, the perceived importance of defense spending varies significantly between the two nations. A higher percentage of U.S. respondents (56%) consider defense spending "Very important" compared to German respondents, who are less inclined to view it as such (15%) [image2]. This indicates a broader acceptance of the necessity of defense spending in the U.S. compared to Germany.

![Views on the U.S. military presence in Germany](image8)

Additionally, the importance of the U.S. military presence in Germany is another area where opinions diverge. About 85% of Americans believe that U.S. military bases in Germany are important to the U.S.'s security interests, while only 59% of Germans agree [8]. This discrepancy highlights the differing perspectives on the role of foreign military bases in national security.

In conclusion, American and German opinions on military intervention and defense spending are notably different, reflecting broader cultural and political differences between the two nations.

Democrats, on the other hand, are more likely to believe the U.S. does too little, with 48% of Democrats saying so, while 26% each think the U.S. does the right amount or too much (text quote [2]).

In terms of specific policy evaluations, the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak is particularly polarized. To summarize, perceptions of the U.S. role in solving world problems are highly polarized along political lines, with Republicans more likely to believe the U.S. does too much, and Democrats more likely to believe the U.S. does too little. These perceptions have become more entrenched over time, as evidenced by the widening partisan gaps in survey data from 2013 to 2020 (image6 and image7).

According to the data, there is a significant difference in views on U.S. global engagement and dealing with domestic issues between Republicans and Democrats, as well as between individuals with varying levels of education.

**Political Affiliation:**

- **Republicans**: A majority of Republicans $(62\%)$ think the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems, while only $8\%$ think it does too little. Among Republicans, a plurality $(48\%)$ say the U.S. does too little to help solve world problems, and $26\%$ say it does the right amount. - **Lower Education**: Conversely, those with lower levels of education tend to favor a more isolationist approach. For example, about four-in-ten of those with a high school degree or less say the U.S. does too much to help solve world problems [11].

![{70% of Americans prioritize human rights over economic relations with China, even if it harms economic relations}](image1)

On the other hand, when it comes to getting tougher with China on trade issues, there is a clear partisan divide. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are much more likely to advocate for a tough stance compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents. Specifically, 72% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents want the U.S. to get tougher on China, with an even higher 81% of conservative Republicans expressing this preference ([12]). Conversely, about 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents prefer to focus on building stronger ties with China, with liberal Democrats being the most supportive of this approach ([12]).

![{Republicans are more likely to want the U.S. to get tougher with China on trade issues compared to Democrats}](image7)

The image1 provides a visual representation of these sentiments. The left bar graph illustrates that 70% of Americans prioritize human rights over economic relations with China, even if it harms economic ties, while the right bar graph shows that 26% of Americans think the U.S. should prioritize economic relations, even if it means not addressing human rights issues. Image7 further reinforces this trend by breaking down the preferences by political affiliation, indicating that Republicans overwhelmingly support getting tougher on China (72%), while Democrats lean towards building a strong relationship (60%).

In summary, different political affiliations in the U.S. view the importance of promoting human rights over economic relations with China and getting tougher on trade issues quite differently. Republicans and conservative Democrats are more inclined to prioritize a tough stance on trade and human rights, whereas Democrats and liberal Democrats tend to favor building stronger economic ties and addressing human rights concerns.

According to the data, there are significant differences in how different political affiliations perceive the impact of trade policies with China and their preferences for dealing with the country. For instance, the image1 shows that Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are more likely to see tariffs on Chinese goods as beneficial for the U.S. (51% of Republicans and 61% of conservative Republicans) compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (only 14% of Democrats and 16% of liberal Democrats).

![{Republicans and Republicans-leaning independents are more positive about tariffs, while Democrats and Democrats-leaning independents are more negative.}](image1)

In addition, the image5 illustrates that Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are much more inclined to prefer a tougher stance with China (72% favor "Get tougher") compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents (37% favor "Get tougher"). This preference is particularly strong among conservative Republicans (81%), who are less likely to support building a strong relationship (18%).

![{Republicans, especially conservatives, prefer a tough stance with China, while Democrats prefer building a strong relationship.}](image5)

Furthermore, the image7 provides insight into the distribution of opinions among different political affiliations regarding the impact of trade policies. The total and Republican/Lean Republican categories show a higher percentage favoring a tough approach (26% and 24% respectively), while the Democratic/Lean Democratic category shows a higher preference for building a strong relationship (70% and 72% respectively). This trend is also evident within the subcategories of Republicans and Democrats, with conservative Republicans being the most likely to support a tough stance (77% and 72% respectively) and liberal Democrats being the most likely to support building a strong relationship (66% and 64% respectively).

![{Opinions on getting tougher or building a strong relationship vary significantly across different political affiliations.}](image7)

In conclusion, different political affiliations in the U.S. view the impact of trade policies with China quite differently, with Republicans and conservative Republicans generally preferring a tougher stance and seeing some benefits from tariffs, while Democrats and liberal Democrats tend to prioritize building a strong relationship and see tariffs as detrimental.

![The perspectives of different political affiliations on the impacts of tariffs and international students in the U.S. vary significantly.](image1)

According to the data, Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals tend to have less confidence in various topics compared to Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals. For instance, when it comes to tariffs, around 51% of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals believe that increased tariffs on Chinese and other foreign products were good for the U.S., whereas only 14% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals agree ([4], [12]). This contrast is even more pronounced within the Republican party, where conservative Republicans are particularly supportive of tariffs, with 61% believing they were good for the U.S., compared to 37% of moderate/liberal Republicans ([4]).

On the other hand, when it comes to international students, the general public sees these students in a positive light. Eight-in-ten Americans say it is good for U.S. colleges and universities to accept international students, while just 19% think the opposite ([11]). However, there are significant differences among political affiliations regarding restrictions on Chinese students. A majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals support limiting Chinese students, with 72% of Republicans and 69% of Republican-leaning individuals opposing the acceptance of Chinese students at U.S. colleges and universities ([8], [12]). In contrast, Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals are more supportive, with only 37% opposing such limitations ([8]).

The image below illustrates these differences more clearly. The total population shows that most have no confidence at all (43%) or not too much confidence (39%) in a certain topic, with Republicans and conservatives showing the highest levels of no confidence ([image1]).

![The total population and different demographic groups' perspectives on tariffs and international students.](image2)

In summary, while the U.S. public generally welcomes international students, there is a stark divide on the issue of Chinese students, particularly along political lines. Republicans are more likely to support limitations on Chinese students, while Democrats are more open to accepting them. This contrasts with the positive view of international students in general, where a majority of the public sees their presence as beneficial for U.S. universities.

![Opinions vary by age and political affiliation](image8)

The opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities vary significantly across different age groups and political affiliations. According to the bar chart in image8, Republicans and those leaning Republican are more likely to support restrictions on Chinese students, with a substantial portion believing that such limitations are "Bad for the U.S." (25%) and "No real effect" (21%), while a majority see it as "Good for the U.S." (51%). Conversely, Democrats and those leaning Democratic are less supportive, with a significant majority seeing no real effect or a positive impact on the U.S. (60% and 14%, respectively).

In terms of age, older Americans are more inclined to support such limitations. As noted in quote [7], around 70% of Americans aged 50 and older favor limiting Chinese students, compared to only 33% among those aged 18 to 29. This trend is consistent with quote [10], which indicates that older Americans are more likely to have no confidence in the Chinese president Xi Jinping.

Furthermore, the image1 bar chart provides insights into public perception regarding the Chinese president, highlighting that older Americans (65 and older) are particularly critical, with 53% expressing no confidence in him, compared to 35% among younger adults (18 to 29 years old). This underscores a strong correlation between age and confidence in Chinese leadership, with older generations showing significantly less trust.

In summary, opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities are closely tied to both age and political affiliation. Older Americans and those with Republican leanings are more likely to support such limitations, reflecting their broader concerns about Chinese influence and leadership.

![Financial Optimism Trends](image5)

From 2004 to 2015, the financial optimism among Hispanic subgroups increased significantly compared to the general public. The chart in image5 shows that the percentage of Hispanics expecting their family’s financial situation to improve "a lot" or "some" rose from 76% in 2004 to 81% in 2015, while the corresponding figure for the general public increased from 70% to 61% during the same period. This indicates a larger increase in optimism among Hispanics, with the gap between the two groups widening to 20 percentage points in 2015.

Additionally, the data from image6 illustrates the specific changes in optimism among Hispanics and the general population from 2008 to 2015. The "All Hispanics" group saw a 14 percentage point increase in optimism, rising from 67% in 2008 to 81% in 2015, while the general population improved by only 6 percentage points, from 56% to 61%.

Moreover, the detailed changes in optimism among different Hispanic subgroups are highlighted in image8. The chart shows that all subgroups, including U.S.-born, foreign-born, males, females, and those with varying levels of education and age groups, experienced significant increases in optimism. Notably, the increase was particularly substantial among those with some college or more (20 percentage points), those aged 18-29 (13 percentage points), and those aged 30-49 (16 percentage points).

In comparison, the general population's optimism also increased, but the growth was more modest, especially among younger and middle-aged individuals. For instance, the optimism among those aged 18-29 and 30-49 increased by 13 and 16 percentage points, respectively, for Hispanics, compared to 7 and 10 percentage points for the general population.

Overall, the financial optimism among Hispanic subgroups has grown more rapidly and substantially since 2008, making them more optimistic than the general population. This trend reflects broader improvements in economic sentiment within the Hispanic community, driven by factors such as educational attainment and generational differences. 

Therefore, the financial optimism among Hispanic subgroups has significantly increased from 2008 to 2015, outpacing the general population, with notable gains across all demographic segments.

According to the data, the current financial situation and educational levels significantly influence the financial expectations of Hispanics for their children. Text quote [1] indicates that Hispanics with a positive view of their current financial situation are more likely to expect their family’s finances to improve in the next year and also see upward mobility for their children. This is supported by the bar chart in image6, which shows the sample sizes and margins of error for different Latino demographic groups, indicating a high level of confidence and optimism among the majority of respondents.

Additionally, text quote [10] highlights that there are differences by educational attainment among Latinos. Specifically, those with at least some college experience are more likely to expect their children to be better off financially, with 69% expecting this outcome. In contrast, those with a high school diploma are even more optimistic, with 79% expecting their children to be better off. This is further illustrated in the segmented bar chart in image8, where individuals in better financial conditions (excellent and good) are more likely to expect significant improvements in their children’s financial future.

In summary, the current financial situation and educational levels play a crucial role in shaping the financial expectations of Hispanics for their children. Those with better financial standing and higher education levels tend to be more optimistic about their children’s future financial prospects. 

![Current financial situation and educational levels influence financial expectations for children](image8)

![The optimism of Hispanics regarding their family's financial improvement has increased since the Great Recession](image4)

From 2004 to 2015, the optimism of Hispanics regarding their family's financial improvement has shown a significant increase, especially compared to the general public. As seen in image4, the percentage of Hispanic adults expecting their family finances to improve "a lot" or "some" rose from 76% in 2004 to 81% in 2015, while the general public's percentage decreased from 70% to 61% over the same period. This trend reflects a more positive outlook among Hispanics, particularly following the Great Recession.

![Unemployment rates for Hispanic and non-Hispanic groups from 2000 to 2015](image7)

Additionally, the unemployment trends for Hispanics and non-Hispanics from 2000 to 2015, as depicted in image7, show that while both groups experienced fluctuations, Hispanic unemployment rates have consistently been higher. The unemployment rate for Hispanics started at 5.8% in 2000 and peaked at 12.8% in the first quarter of 2010, during the Great Recession. It then dropped to 6.4% by the end of 2015. In comparison, the non-Hispanic unemployment rate began at 3.8% in 2000 and reached a peak of 10.1% in the second quarter of 2010, before dropping to 4.8% by the end of 2015. Despite the improvements, the unemployment rate for Hispanics remains higher than that for non-Hispanics.

In summary, while the optimism of Hispanics regarding their financial well-being has increased significantly since the Great Recession, their unemployment rates remain higher compared to the general public and non-Hispanic groups.

According to the data, the trends in unemployment rates and economic perceptions differ significantly between Hispanic and non-Hispanic populations. The unemployment rate for Hispanic workers has shown a consistent upward trend since the Great Recession, peaking at 12.8% in the first quarter of 2010 and declining to 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015 (and 5.6% in the first quarter of 2016), still remaining higher than the non-Hispanic unemployment rate, which peaked at 10% in the same period and fell to 4.8% by 2015 [8]. This is illustrated in the line graph from image8, where the Hispanic unemployment rate is consistently higher than the non-Hispanic rate across the recession periods and subsequent recovery phases.

In terms of economic perceptions, the Pew Research Center surveys reveal that Hispanic adults tend to be more optimistic about the national economy. In a December 2015 survey, 35% of Hispanics rated current economic conditions as good or excellent, a higher percentage than the 25% reported among non-Hispanic whites [5]. Additionally, a greater proportion of Hispanics (34%) expect economic conditions to improve in the coming year, compared to other groups of Americans [5]. This optimism is further supported by the data showing that Latino views of their financial situation are more positive now than in 2004, while the public's view of its finances is lower [6].

However, despite this optimism, the economic reality for Hispanic households is marked by significant disparities in income and wealth. Median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, with a median income of $42,491 in 2014, essentially unchanged from the recession period [2]. Moreover, the Hispanic poverty rate in 2014 was 23.6%, lower than the peak of 26.5% in 2010 but still above pre-recession levels [2]. The wealth gap is stark, with Hispanic households having the largest percentage decline in their net worth through 2009 compared to other racial or ethnic groups, and their net worth continued to fall after the recession [2].

These trends are visually depicted in image2, which shows the disparity in median household income, poverty rates, and wealth between Hispanic and all U.S. households over time. The left graph indicates that Hispanic households have a median income lower than the national average, the middle graph shows a significantly higher poverty rate, and the right graph illustrates a much lower median wealth compared to the national average.

The data also highlight that economic perceptions among Hispanic subgroups vary. For instance, Latinos with some college experience or more and U.S.-born Latinos are more likely to say their personal financial situation is excellent or good, while those with less than a high school education or who are immigrants are less optimistic [9]. This is evident in the bar chart from image3, which shows a general increase in support or approval among all groups from 2008 to 2015, with notable increases among U.S. born and those with some college or more.

In conclusion, while Hispanic populations exhibit more optimism about economic conditions, the underlying economic realities, including stagnant income, persistent poverty rates, and declining wealth, continue to pose challenges. These disparities contribute to the ongoing economic and social inequalities faced by the Hispanic community. 

![Economic perceptions and unemployment rates](image6)

The economic challenges faced by Hispanic households from 2000 to 2015 can be compared to those of all U.S. households using several key metrics: unemployment rates, median household income, poverty rates, and wealth. 

According to image5, which presents three line graphs comparing financial metrics, Hispanic households have consistently lower median household incomes, higher poverty rates, and less wealth compared to all U.S. households. Specifically, in 2014, Hispanic households had a median income of $42,500, which is significantly lower than the median income for all U.S. households at $53,700. Additionally, the poverty rate for Hispanic households was 23.6% in 2014, compared to 14.8% for all U.S. households. Moreover, in 2013, Hispanic households had a median wealth of $13,700, whereas all U.S. households had a median wealth of $81,400.

On the other hand, image6 provides a visual representation of unemployment rates for Hispanic and non-Hispanic groups from 2000 to 2015. While the graph shows fluctuations, it highlights that Hispanic unemployment rates have generally been higher than those of non-Hispanics. For instance, in 2000, the unemployment rate for Hispanic households was 5.8%, which rose to 12.8% during the Great Recession (shaded area) and then decreased to 6.4% by 2015. Non-Hispanic unemployment rates started at 3.8% in 2000, reached a peak of 5.9% during the recession, and ended at 4.8% in 2015.

![Unemployment rates for Hispanic and non-Hispanic groups](image6)

Furthermore, image5's right graph clearly illustrates the disparity in wealth, showing that in 2013, Hispanic households had a median wealth of $13,700, while all U.S. households had a much higher median wealth of $81,400. The left graph confirms that Hispanic households have had lower median incomes over the period, and the middle graph indicates higher poverty rates for Hispanic households.

In summary, Hispanic households have faced greater economic challenges compared to all U.S. households, evidenced by higher unemployment rates, lower median incomes, higher poverty rates, and less accumulated wealth. These disparities are consistent with the data presented in the provided quotes and images.

According to the survey, educational attainment significantly influences perceptions of workforce technologies. Many Americans anticipate significant advancements in automation technologies, particularly in the development and adoption of driverless vehicles. However, their current experiences with various technologies reveal a mixed picture. For instance, when asked about the impact of technologies such as word processing or spreadsheet software, smartphones, and email or social media on their careers, workers express more positive views than negative ones. This suggests that while some technologies like driverless vehicles are seen as promising in the future, the current experiences with others like industrial robots are more mixed or negative.

Moreover, the impact of automation technologies on employment and wages is already being felt, with a small but significant portion of workers experiencing job losses or wage reductions. According to [5] and [10], approximately $2\%-5\%$ of U.S. adults have lost jobs or had their pay or hours reduced due to workforce automation. The data in [5] and [10] further break down this impact by demographic groups, revealing that younger adults, lower-income individuals, and those with less education are disproportionately affected.

In summary, while there is optimism about future advancements in driverless vehicles and other automation technologies, the current experiences of U.S. workers with various technologies are more varied, with some technologies being viewed positively and others negatively. The perception of industrial robots, in particular, is more negative compared to other technologies, suggesting a gap between anticipated and realized impacts of automation.

![Support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs](image1)
According to the bar chart in image1, there is a strong alignment between Democrats and Republicans regarding the support for limiting machines to dangerous and unhealthy jobs. Specifically, 85% of Americans favor this type of policy, with nearly half strongly supporting it. This high level of agreement underscores a general consensus on the desirability of restricting automation to hazardous tasks.

Furthermore, the data from text quote [11] reinforces this point: "Public is strongly supportive of limiting robots and computers to 'dangerous and dirty' jobs, responds favorably to policy solutions such as a universal basic income or national service program for displaced workers." This indicates that the majority of the population, irrespective of political affiliation, agrees that machines should primarily perform dangerous or unhealthy tasks.

However, when it comes to specific policies like a universal basic income or a national service program, there are notable differences between Democrats and Republicans. Text quote [1] highlights that Democrats are significantly more supportive of these policies compared to Republicans. For instance, 77% of Democrats favor a universal basic income, whereas only 38% of Republicans do, and 66% of Democrats support a national service program for displaced workers, compared to 46% of Republicans.

In summary, while there is broad support across the political spectrum for limiting machines to dangerous jobs, there are marked differences in support for other policies aimed at mitigating the impacts of automation. Democrats tend to be more favorable toward comprehensive support measures like universal basic income and national service programs, whereas Republicans are more inclined to prioritize individual responsibility.

![There is significant variation in opinions on government obligations and automation limits based on political affiliation and education levels](image8)

Political affiliations play a crucial role in shaping opinions on both government obligations and automation limits. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are much more supportive of the government taking care of workers displaced by automation, with 65% and 68% respectively believing the government has an obligation to do so, even if it means higher taxes. In contrast, a larger share of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (68%) feel that individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being, even if jobs are automated on a wide scale. This aligns with data showing that 30% of Republicans/lean Republican and 65% of Democrats/lean Democrat believe the government has an obligation to care for displaced workers.

Educational attainment also influences opinions on these issues. Those with lower levels of educational attainment are more supportive of imposing limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines. For instance, 70% of those with high school diplomas or less support such limits, compared to 41% among those with four-year college degrees. This trend is consistent across both government obligations and automation limits, with Democrats and those with higher education levels generally being more supportive of government intervention and limits on automation.

Overall, political affiliation and education level significantly shape opinions on government obligations and automation limits. Democrats and those with higher education are more likely to advocate for government support and limitations on automation, whereas Republicans and those with lower education levels tend to prioritize individual responsibility and fewer restrictions on automation. 

Therefore, political affiliation and education levels strongly influence opinions on government obligations and automation limits related to job displacement.
